title: England players should have walked off as cancer of racism showed itself again
text:

The goals were immaterial. The dominance a footnote.

By the end of the first 45 minutes in Bulgaria, a football match became a test of whether world football is still prepared to tolerate young black men being abused on the basis of the colour of their skin.

Answer: It is. In this sport the game comes first at any cost. So they played on.

Would we ask female athletes to perform through clearly audible sexist abuse? No we wouldn’t.

Would we stomach homophobic abuse? Same answer.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Yet thugs around the world continue to get chance after chance to hurl their racist filth and nazi salutes at black footballers.

One day we will look back and wonder how on earth we could have allowed this to happen.

For now - yet again - we’ve left it to the authorities. Let’s find out what they actually do.

Bear in mind the officials didn’t even acknowledge the first-half monkey chanting until they were alerted to it by the Aston Villa defender Tyrone Mings. What a sad England debut for him.

(Image: Andy Commins / Daily Mirror)

Added to that, on past form UEFA, European football’s governing body, has shown itself utterly incapable of ensuring the punishment for racism fits the crime. Why should this occasion be any different? With zero black representation at decision-making level they simply don’t care.

Expect a fine of around £100,000 for Bulgaria in a few months time.

Home fans were turning up to the stadium wearing tops emblazoned with the message: ‘UEFA Mafia - No respect’.

Yes, after the second appeal on the PA system for the Bulgarian ultras to stop abusing England’s black stars a significant number of them left.

But the abuse did not go away in the second half.

(Image: Getty Images)

For all the triumphalism about the success of the three-step protocol - warning fans to stop or risk seeing the game abandoned - many will feel it did not work.

UEFA argued during the second half that there were only ‘isolated’ pockets of abuse during the second half. So that’s alright then.

The truth is that the black players don’t want to experience any of it, their white colleagues don’t want to have to support them through it and we as a public are sick of having to witness it. They should have walked off.

The England stars in Bulgaria later explained they wanted to continue the game. The widely-held view, however, it that it is bigger than them. It is about drawing a line in the sand for all of us.

(Image: Sportimage)

(Image: GEORGI LICOVSKI/EPA-EFE/REX)

At some point a high-profile player or team will have to do what NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick did when he took a knee?

Or what Jon Carlos and Tommie Smith did with their Black Power salute at the 1969 Olympics in pursuit of social justice. Sometimes the issue is bigger than the sport.

And what to do about Bulgaria? The answer is simple.

Throw countries guilty of racist behaviour out of competitions. Internationally and domestically. Issue them with a suspended sentence ahead of the other forthcoming competitions. If they offend again, they are out.

Draconian maybe but a solution that would send shock waves through a lot of countries - and clubs. It would also focus a few minds here in England on actually getting their house in order.

Fines don’t work. Nor do stadium closures. Slogans don’t work. Soundbites and condemnations aren’t worth the paper they are written on.

Football has had decades to address the cancer of racism with which it is riddled.

It has taken the full, naked, ugly truth to present itself in a crucial match in a major competition for the wider world to wake up.
description: England stars suffered racist abuse at the hands of Bulgaria fans during their Euro 2020 qualifier against Bulgaria
